I don't think there's a single moment in this movie where the underwater shots that was gratuitous or needed to be cut, they all had a purpose. In the beginning the kids are experiencing the underwater world for the first time after living their entire lives in the forest and learn they have a lot of training to do and discover new things they never would've imagined like the sign language used by the sea people. Over time they become more comfortable and even riding the dolphin like creatures showing their growth which you need to see happen instead of hearing a one line from a character, that would feel cheap and unearned. Then Lo'ak almost gets killed by a giant shark and then saved by Payakan whom he quickly befriends for saving his life, with this in mind he decides to take the blame for the other kids who put him in that dangerous situation instead of seeking revenge. Later after hearing Payakan is an outcast Lo'ak befriends the whale even more because he feels a kinship because he too feels like an outcast.

The characters are extremely weak bar quaritch and the outcast whale, spider and jake are particularly bad.
The entire middle hour copies the first movie when the first is already chided for a lack of originality.

I could probably dig deep into Quaritch coming back to life but Stephen Lang just has too much fun chewing the scenery for me to care
It's honestly great eye candy, but I just think the movie's greatest weakness is its characters and the story focused on family connection, so I just believe it falls flat entirely.

posts.name: Anonymous
posts.com:
The Special Edition (formerly Assembly Cut) is very good, and the theatrical cut isn't that bad.

Basically, Alien 3 developed a hatedom because of Aliens fans who felt it was "disrespectful" to Aliens, particularly because it killed off Newt and Hicks offscreen. The closest parallel possible is Resident Evil: The Final Chapter, which killed off almost all the characters from the previous film, and went for a very bleak and aggressive tone. Some people think it's "disrespectful" for a film like Alien 3 to kill all the characters they like, and then kill the main character, because "it makes it all pointless", but Alien 3 is a bleak reality check against the action foolishness of Aliens. It's like Terminator 3 without the levity.

Alien 3, I think, benefits from its rich atmosphere and generous pacing. It's a movie that really sinks in.

>I think I might have watched the theatrical cut, so I'll absolutely watch the Assembly Cut later on.
If the Xeno came out a dog, it was the theatrical cut. If it was an ox/cow, it was the special edition. The biggest difference between the cuts is the depth of characterization for the prisoners.

Oh, wait. There's an even more significant difference.

In the theatrical cut, the chest burster comes out of Ripley as she falls into the fire. In the special edition, it doesn't, preserving the ambiguity that she could have taken Weyland's offer and been saved. In the theatrical cut, his offer of salvation doesn't make sense because she was second away from chest bursting.

Alien (Theatrical) is a beautifully crafted horror film.
Aliens (Extended) is a pulse pounding horror action film.
Alien 3 (SE) is a brutal, despairing horror film that overcomes so many production issues to shine with a rare brilliance.
Alien Resurrection (DC) is a mixed bag but it has a sense of imagination and it has the most intelligent and cunning Xenos in the franchise.
Alien vs Predator (Unrated) is a pulpy take on Alien with a lot of cool ideas, but it doesn't breathe as much as the better Alien films do.
Alien vs Predator 2 is dogshit.
Prometheus is AvP without any sense of fun.
Alien: Covenant is Ridley Scott sadly going senile in his old age, taking the basic trope of scientists doing retarded shit and ramping it up to infinity.

>>178511571
There's a couple main issues.
first is time delay, even a delay of one second can be disastrous in a combat situation, so it's fine for the bulldozers which essentially just have to move in straight lines demolishing everything in their path, but for the helicopters that won't work.
The second is that Jake and the Na'vi use the Flux Vortex to stage their bases and combat encounters. The Vortex completely screws up instrumentation, so using a drone is out because it essentially wouldn't be able to see anything, also there's the possibility that the computing power to have a drone react as fast as human doesn't exist.
The canopies are a weak spot for sure, but the visibility requirements outweigh the risk factors. We know the glass is strong enough to deflect Na'vi arrows that aren't straight on or are fired from a distance (the Na'vi firing at Quaritch's dragon canopy in the first film during the tree bombardment scene), but from a few feet away straight on, I doubt even the metal of the helicopters is strong enough to protect the pilots.

>Participant:

>Jonathan Rosenbaum, critic (joinathanrosenbaum.net) and sometime educator (FilmFactory, KinoKlub in Split), United States

>Films:

>1.The Banshees of Inisherin, Martin McDonagh, 2022

>Memoria, Apichatpong Weerasethakul, 2021

>Men, Alex Garland, 2022

>Potemkinistii, Radu Jude, 2022

>Wheel of Fortune and Fantasy, Ryûsuke Hamaguchi, 2021

>I have conflicted relations to all five – even Memoria, the only one I’ve seen twice and which I’m still trying to understand. The Jude film is a short, and the Hamaguchi feature beautifully juxtaposes three formally and thematically related shorts.

>The Banshees is the first McDonagh film I’ve halfway liked–much as Tár, its big-city near-equivalent in social critique, is the first Todd Field film I’ve halfway liked. But the facile defeatism of both features depresses me: small-town stupidity and brutality motored by a colossal sense of entitlement, big-city smarts comparably preening and braying through the brutality of celebrity culture. Both register like bad jokes told with enough sarcastic relish and wit to make them sporadically blossom out of their gnarled bitterness into something resembling good jokes
>2. American: An Odyssey to 1947, Danny Wu, 2022. This documentary about Orson Welles’ politics in the 30s and 40s doesn’t even have a distributor yet, but it taught me a lot. If I had room for a short, I’d include Nisam je stigao voljeti/I Didn’t Get to Love Her (2022) by Anna Fernandez, a former FilmFactory student who shot it in Sarajevo but edited it years later in Spain, especially for its rhythm and framing.

>3. The Fabelmans, Steven Spielberg, 2022. Not my favorite Spielberg, but the nerviest. Ross Lipman’s The Case of the Vanishing Gods is almost as nervy and every bit as scary.

>4. The Runner, Amir Naderi, 1984. My best guess as to why this remarkable and innovative autobiographical feature was held up for 38 years: the need to clear various song rights.

He's a very talented actor. Watching the latest Star Wars trilogy you can tell he's the most talented person there and how much he cares for the character he plays, which is something that is visible in all of his other works as well. His method of acting is personal and sincere, the best example being his performance in the film Paterson, one of my favorite movies he's in, which I recommend you watch if you want to see what I'm talking about. When he is onscreen is easy to forget you're watching an actor portray a character and not a real person's day to day life.
When it comes to Adam Driver as a person I also find him fascinating. He's passionate about acting but terrified of being in the spotlight, which is something I can relate to. He keeps to himself and doesn't see himself as a celebrity, and I respect that. In the interviews I've seen of him and his TED Talk he seems like a very real, relatable person who doesn't think he's got life figured out yet and is just doing what he loves and loving what he does, which I find inspiring. I also find him truly attractive. There's just something about him that calls to me, if that makes sense.

>>178508771
David Foster Wallace once wrote a piece about David Lynch. In the piece, he coined a new term: "Lynchian". Wallace described a Lynchian tone as "the unbelievably grotesque existing in a kind of union with the unbelievably banal."

He described a husband beating his 1950s housewife to death because she bought the wrong brand of peanut butter. "I told you to buy the JIF," he'd say as he's clobbering her to death. This, he said, would qualify as almost perfectly Lynchian.

I think "I Am Jazz" enters into Lynchian territory. The .webm above shows a simple domestic scene. The women look like average suburban moms. They're relaxing on the couch. One imagines they might be discussing casserole recipes when we cut to them. But it slowly dawns on us that in the living room, with placid expressions on their faces, they're talking about the woman's transvestite son's genitals.

Despite the obvious subtext and the producers' hope to normalize this horror, the average person is totally disgusted. Nevertheless, the viewer is fascinated. We're drawn further into this. The sheer naked horror of what they're saying, the blasé quality with which they're saying it, it creates this brutal paradox that almost rapes the viewer's basic sense of what is decent.

I'm a trans individual who has been on /tv/ for years. I've yet to see any definitive proof that anything which is largely accepted by the trans community is bad for them, and I'm here to address these issues.

Let's get a hot topic out of the way first: gender reassignment surgery is as necessary for individuals experiencing severe gender dysphoria as chemo would be for a cancer patient. Yes, some people still unfortunately kill themselves. But, every single person who undergoes surgery who doesnt is a person whose life is saved. It is not cosmetic, it is life saving.

Secondly, estrogen is not bad for your mind or body in any way as an assigned-at-birth male. There is zero scientific evidence that it is. This is baseless and only serves to scare people away from taking the medicine they need

Third: it can be "too late to change". I am 37 and I only began hrt 5 years ago. Within two years I was visually passing and now my voice sounds indistinguishable from any other woman's.

Finally, that it is bad for children to transition. Most children have no issue with this and think it's cool to know a trans individual. And giving children estrogen does in fact make it easier on them psychologically to go through their lives as a woman. There is zero evidence that any child has experienced adverse effects growing up compared to non-trans children.

I will talk to anyone about any of these things. I'm just sick of seeing baseless bullshit spewed about us on this board. Seeing that stuff early on in my transition made me think about some things I never want to think about again. And anyone who posts pictures of girls who are having trouble passing is participating in psychological abuse.

>>178528564
One of the great facets of the dullest franchise in the history of movie franchises. Each episode following the boy wizard and his pals from Hogwarts Academy as they fight assorted villains has been indistinguishable from the others. Aside from the gloomy imagery, the series’ only consistency has been its lack of excitement and ineffective use of special effects, all to make magic unmagical, to make action seem inert.

Perhaps the die was cast when Rowling vetoed the idea of Spielberg directing the series; she made sure the series would never be mistaken for a work of art that meant anything to anybody, just ridiculously profitable cross-promotion for her books. The Harry Potter series might be anti-Christian (or not), but it’s certainly the anti-James Bond series in its refusal of wonder, beauty and excitement. No one wants to face that fact. Now, thankfully, they no longer have to.

>a-at least the books were good though
"No!"
The writing is dreadful; the book was terrible. As I read, I noticed that every time a character went for a walk, the author wrote instead that the character "stretched his legs."

I began marking on the back of an envelope every time that phrase was repeated. I stopped only after I had marked the envelope several dozen times. I was incredulous. Rowling's mind is so governed by cliches and dead metaphors that she has no other style of writing. Later I read a lavish, loving review of Harry Potter by the same Stephen King. He wrote something to the effect of, "If these kids are reading Harry Potter at 11 or 12, then when they get older they will go on to read Stephen King." And he was quite right. He was not being ironic. When you read "Harry Potter" you are, in fact, trained to read Stephen King.

>>178499946
>They'd just pay their friend to produce them and buy them at exorbitant prices, pocket a kickback and charge it all to the fed

CRT TVs require a whole massive dedicated factory to create. It's also a very delicate process to form and shape the glass tube so it properly displays pictures correctly. One mistake and the whole TV becomes useless. A lot of chemicals and gasses are involved too. They have to coat in the inner glass of the CRT tube in layers of very specific chemicals. There is no way to cheaply do it.

A "couple orders from a prison" wouldn't even be worth the costs of turning on the lights at a CRT factory.

When the last CRT factory closed in the West, China bought all the manufacturing CRT equipment.

The Chinese thought they could make cheap CRTs and announced they would make CRTs for everyone. But then China found out that's its really fucking hard to make CRTs. It requires skill and it doesn't matter how many bodies you throw at the problem. You need trained CRT techs to make them without fucking it up.

China kept messing up the glass making process and after several years they announced they couldn't do it. China then scrapped all the CRT manufacturering equipment and melted it down for scrap.

No more CRT manufacturering equipment exists anymore China bought and destroyed the last of it after they failed.

Bullshit, I did two years and while the cable system sucked ass through a straw, they bought (or maybe pirated) every major release and a lot of obscure shit. Every week the movie list changed, we had a special movie channel that just played what discs they had. I watched Three From Hell in prison. It sucked. I just mention it because it's the most definitely not PG movie I remember seeing in there, but you name it we saw it. First time I saw Joker was in prison, same with Avengers: End Game. Sometimes we'd get some weird more obscure shit like this documentary called Ramenheads.

>>178499733
This is accurate. All electronics inside look like this. The rules vary from prison to prison but you can only order new items from catalogs and some stuff from Amazon. I ordered a shitload of books and it's basically /tg/ heaven in there, everyone's playing D&D and Magic: The Gathering and much more obscure shit. Everyone's reading manga too. I checked out every sci-fi and fantasy novel in the library, got to a point I was reading science manuals to pass the time because I was running out of books. The librarian took a shine to me (or was trying to curry favor or something, I don't know) and kept loaning me his manga, and it was some pretty ecchi shit. Highschool of the Dead, A Certain Scientific Railgun, Gleipnir, Yokai girls...

I remember being annoyed because they wouldn't approve me ordering a pillow through Amazon. The ones they gave us were shit.

posts.name: Anonymous
posts.com:
>>178526944
>>178527233
The reason why film has always been 24fps is because it's...film. The standardization of 24 was about producing acceptable motion as economically efficient as possible. 24 was the lowest number of frames that looked natural. The advent of digital has made this standard arbitrary.

TWOW is mostly digital environments and characters so it's actually impossible to get the effect of "these are people on a set" that 48fps has given productions in the past (Hobbit - Gemini Man).

The correction of this effect is aided by the cinematography of the film as well. While the first film relied on handheld and documentary style footage shot by Cameron himself to augment the realism of the environment (something that could negatively impact 48fps shots), TWOW didn't need to do this because of it's hyperreal CGI. Cameron instead brought on the DOP of Titanic and True Lies, Russel Carpenter to shoot this film.

The problem therefore lies in Cameron's decision to overcorrect. The film was distributed at variable frame rate, meaning certain non action shots switch to 24fps in order to maintain cinematic movements between characters. This doesn't work quite well because modern projectors can't just switch native frame rate on the fly. So instead of 24fps you have 48fps shots where each frame plays twice. This noticeably looks slow.

I will reiterate that 48fps looks really good for this movie (something I can't say about other films that have tried it). They should've just not done the VFR. I would recommend watching the film at either frame rate as it looks spectacular no matter what, but if the framerate shift is likely to distract your viewing I would say make your first viewing 3D @ 24fps - (although it should be mentioned that the 3D is enhanced by HFR).
